title: DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION
author: Eddie Robson (004) Page I
filename: 145 - Industrial Evolution - Eddie Robson & Jonathan Morris_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
GRAMS DOCTOR WHO THEME
SCENE 1. INT. CELLAR
F/X DISTANT RUMBLE OF MACHINERY. DOORS OPEN. GRENVILLE, A
GRUMBLY OLD LANCASTRIAN, MAKES HIS WAY DOWN SOME STEPS.

Go down to the cellar, says Mr Townsend. It’s alright for him, he’s not the one gonna break his neck falling down the stairs. Fetch us some pigtail bolts, he says. He’s not the one as has to root around in the pitch dark without even a gas lamp —
F/X DOOR SLAMS.
Hoi! Someone’s down here, you gawby! How am I supposed to fetch owt if I can’t even see my hand in front of my face?
F/X CLINK OF MOVING METAL. FOOTSTEPS ON STONE FLOOR.
What’s that? Who’s there? I can hear you, mullocking around —
F/X CLINK OF MOVING METAL, CLOSER LOUDER.
Alright, you’ve had your laugh, now show yourself —
F/X SUDDEN LOUD CRASH OF ADVANCING METAL. GRENVILLE SCREAMS,
HIS SCREAM MERGING INTO THE SOUND OF:
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 3
SCENE 2. INT. FACTORY
F/X STEAM WHISTLE BLOWS. RACKET OF MACHINERY ALL AROUND.
BREWSTER IS LOADING METAL SHEETS INTO A LATHE, STEPHEN CUTTING THEM.
You’re not from round these parts?
Are you talking to me?
Aye. You’re in the union now. We don’t talk to those as aren’t in the union. Where were you before you were here, then?
Oh, around and about. London. It’s Stephen, isn’t it?
That’s right, Brewster.
You know my name.
F/X CUTTING METAL.
It’s my business to know the name of every union man — Mind your fingers, lathe’ll have ‘em clean off!
sorry.
You’ve travelled, then, Brewster?
Yeah. There’s more to life than one little town in Lancashire.
I wouldn’t know about that. No man’s limited by what he sees around him.
If you say so. But most people, they think the world ends at the end of their street. They never stop to imagine there might be more out there.
So what is out there?
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 4
You wouldn’t believe me if I told you. I saw things that you’d Swear were impossible. Even to me, it all seems like a dream.
Oh. A dream. Right.
Don’t get me wrong. I’m not knocking the factory, or Ackleton. It’s a wage, and I’m grateful. But imagine seeing everything else that was out there - and then losing it.
So you’ve travelled a lot, then, have you?
Oh, and then some.
Because in my experience, Brewster, those who live the travelling lifestyle are either gypsies, actors or crooks.
(BEAT) Yeah, I was an actor.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 5
SCENE 3. EXT. FACTORY YARD
F/X MACHINERY NOISE IN BACKGROUND. CLARA PENCIL SKETCHING —
SCRATCHES ON PAPER.
Still not finished your sketch, Miss Stretton?
F/X BREWSTER ENTERS, WALKS THEIR WAY.
I am making further studies, Mr Townsend. Considering the subject from varying angles, to ascertain how it might be shown off to the best advantage.
(OFF) Morning, Miss Stretton!
I’ve told you, Brewster, you’re not to bother Miss Stretton when she’s on the site. Or any other time for that matter.
Brewster doesn’t bother me.
F/X BREWSTER ARRIVES NEXT TO THEM, STOPS.
Glad to hear it, miss.
Wouldn’t a young lady like you prefer to draw a nice meadow?

Oh no. Everything in the fields does tend to sway so in the wind. And then some horse or cow wanders into view, and one feels obliged to include it, but that entails all the tedious business of drawing its legs. No, my limited skills are far better suited to the straight lines and rough textures of modern buildings.
If you say so. What are you doing out here, Brewster?
Just getting some fresh rainwater, sir.
Then be rapid about it, lad.
F/X TOWNSEND LEAVES. BREWSTER POURS SOME WATER INTO A BUCKET.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 6
The way he goes on, you’d think he doesn’t trust you to be left alone with me.
And with good reason.
What?

The sketching is simply a ruse. You don’t have to compliment me, I know I’m an altogether useless artist. But people will humour a young woman in almost any activity, regardless of merit, so long as it is harmless and appropriate.
So what are you doing here?
I consider that the workers’ conditions here are unacceptable. I am gathering observations to lend my arguments weight.
Blimey. Not really what Mr Townsend would call harmless or appropriate!
(LAUGHS) Then it is just as well that in this matter, as in so many others, he remains in blissful ignorance!
F/X FROM WITHIN THE FACTORY, AND VERY LOUD:
(OFF) AAAAAAAAARGH!
What in heaven’s name was [that-?]
Stephen.
F/X RUSH OFF INTO:
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 7
SCENE 4. INT. FACTORY (FLOOR)
F/X BREWSTER AND CLARA DASH INSIDE TO FIND STEPHEN WRITHING
IN AGONY. CONSTERNATION AROUND HIM, SOME MACHINES STILL GOING, SOME NOT.
Is he all right? / Dear God! / How did it happen? / Did you see it?
Mr Gibson! Oh my goodness -
(CALLS) Someone fetch a doctor! Quick!

There is no doctor in the town, but a friend of my father’s is here at the factory, and he is a doctor. Well, he is an engineer by profession, but his medical knowledge equals that of any physician I’ve met -
Never mind the life story, can you get him here now?
F/X CLARA OPENS THE DOOR.
Ah, he is coming already. He must have heard the disturbance.
That’s quite a stroke of luck, isn’t... (SEES THE DOCTOR ENTERING) .. Oh, or maybe it’s not.
(RUSHING TO STEPHEN’S SIDE) What’s happened?
Dr Smith. This poor man was working at the lathe — I fear his
fingers are severed.
(TO DOCTOR) What are you doing here? I thought —
What does it look like I’m doing? Helping.
F/X EVELYN ARRIVES.
Oh! Good grief. The poor fellow!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 8
Evelyn, could you pop across to our lodgings and fetch the medical kit?
Of course.
F/X EVELYN DASHES AWAY.
Someone should inform Mr Townsend. If you will excuse me...
F/X CLARA LEAVES.
Brewster, get me some water. Hot, but not boiling.
I thought you’d left, you said — [you were]
Never mind that now. We need to clean the wound. Water!
F/X BREWSTER LEAVES.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 9
SCENE 5. INT. FACTORY (OFFICE)
F/X TOWNSEND WRITING IN A LEDGER. CLARA BURSTS IN.
Mr Townsend!
Miss Stretton. Would you mind if I finish entering [these figures —]
I most certainly would. Have you not heard the commotion?
I have, and I was poised to investigate [just as soon —]
One of your workers has suffered the most appalling injury.
Is he deceased?
No, but —
Well, then it’s not the most appalling injury.
He has lost three fingers.
Which worker?
Stephen Gibson.
(TUTS) Ah, a good worker. When he wants to be. Agitator though.
I don’t feel you are treating this accident with the appropriate solemnity, Mr Townsend.

Not at all, Miss Stretton. I am greatly concerned by this incident. The fewer fingers a man has, the less work he will be able to do. If I was mathematically inclined, I daresay I could even go so far as to calculate the precise formula.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 10
Might I suggest your time might be better spent tackling this institution’s scandalously poor record on safety!
And might I suggest, young lady, that you would do better to concentrate on your daubings than to tell me my business!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page I]
SCENE 6. INT. FACTORY FLOOR
F/X THE DOCTOR IS CLEANING STEPHEN’S WOUNDS. A CROWD OF
WORKERS STANDS NEARBY AND MUTTERS ABOUT THE SITUATION.
Aaaah!
I’m sorry, but please, I need you to hold still.
What is it you’re doing, Doctor?
Trying to prevent him losing the rest of his hand.
What? Is that all?
(LOW) What more do you expect?
(LOW) Come on, I’ve seen what can you can do.
(LOW) Brewster, this is neither the time nor the place...
F/X EVELYN RETURNS.
Ah! Evelyn, what took you so long?
Never mind a ‘thank you’! Here’s the medical kit.
F/X DOCTOR OPENS THE KIT.
(DRAWING UP SYRINGE) Now. Mr Gibson. This — is what is known as a syringe...
(ALARMED) You’re not to stick that - thing in me!
It’s alright, Stephen. I know the Doctor, you can trust him.
(BEAT) Alright, if you — (say so).
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 12
F/X DOCTOR STICKS THE NEEDLE IN.
Aaaah! I thought you said I could trust him?
You can. I’m the one you shouldn’t trust.
I’1ll remember that. (WINCES IN PAIN)
Try to think about something else.
The pain should start to go away. And this should clear any infection...
F/X STARTS DRESSING THE WOUND.
Now, leave the dressing on for at least five hours and keep your arm upright, like this. You understand?
Thank... thank you, Doctor.
That’s all right. Lucky thing I was here, eh?
F/X DOCTOR STANDS.
Someone should take him home. / Yes, he’s in a bad way. / Can you take him?
So, now you’ve played the hero, why don’t you just brush off?
Charming. I didn’t expect gratitude — (but)
Why are you two doing around here, anyway? I thought I was well rid of you!
Don’t be like that, Thomas. We’re here to see the owner of the factory.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 13
You’re wasting your time. He’s still off on holiday. I haven’t seen him myself yet. Now, if you don’t mind, I’ve gotta sort out getting Stephen home.
F/X BREWSTER LEAVES.
He doesn’t seem too pleased to see us again, does he?
Yes, but to be honest, Thomas Brewster’s feelings are the least of my worries right now. What concerns me is what happened to Stephen...
The accident, you mean?
If it was an accident...
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 14
SCENE 7. INT. FACTORY (OFFICE)
F/X AS BEFORE.
The machines are not at fault, Miss Stretton. They are of the latest design, of the highest quality manufacture, and were acquired by Mr Belfrage at great personal expense —
(MUTTER) Whereas your workforce was acquired at the smallest possible expense.
— and are serviced quite regularly. Mr Belfrage does not cut
corners. It’s not his fault if the Lancastrian working man’s
mind will not adapt from the manufacture of cotton and silk.
We should be grateful he hasn’t already sold up and relocated to Wales or Cornwall where, I am told, the workforce is much
more amenable and at a fraction of the cost.
Is that where he is now?
No, Mr Belfrage is currently domiciled in Venice. I was contemplating hypotheticals, Miss. Hypotheticals!
F/X KNOCK AT DOOR.
Enter!
F/X BREWSTER ENTERS.
Yes, Brewster? What is it? Spit it out.
The Doctor’s patched up Stephen’s hand and sent him home, Mr Townsend. Robert Askew’s gone with him.
What, so now we’re two men down?
Oh. And the Doctor says he wants to see you.
About the accident?
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 15
No, about Mr Belfrage. He’s waiting in the boss’s office.
(SIGH) And you left him in there unattended, I suppose?
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 16
SCENE 8. INT. BELFRAGE’S OFFICE
F/X A ROOM AT THE FACTORY. THE DOCTOR IS SNOOPING AROUND,
OPENING DRAWERS AND RIFLING THROUGH.
Doctor, should you be going through Belfrage’s drawers?
No, absolutely not. But you know me, Evelyn, I can resist everything but temptation... (DISCOVERY) Ah-ha!
What is it? Have you found something?
No, nothing at all. Either Mr Belfrage has a very good memory, or somebody else does his book-keeping, because — Hello!
What?
F/X DOCTOR BENDS DOWN.
Look, here — wedged between the floorboards.
Looks like a.. pocket torch?
No. Whatever it is, it’s far in advance of your time, never mind the 19th century.
F/X DOCTOR TRIES TO PICK IT UP.
Funny... can’t get it to budge...
Shouldn’t you leave it where it is? I expect Mr Belfrage will be rather upset if he notices it’s gone missing.
I don’t care if he is. I want to know what this thing is, and I don’t intend to leave it lying around for any Tom, Dick or Harry -
F/X FOOTSTEPS COMING UP STAIRS OUTSIDE.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 17
Doctor, someone’s coming.
Just needs one more twist and —
F/X METALLIC SNAP.
There, got it! Very odd, though — it seemed to be almost growing from between the floorboards...
Doctor, put it away before —
F/X DOOR OPENS, TOWNSEND ENTERS.
(BEAT) May I ask what you two are doing in here?
Er, admiring the view.
All you can see from here is the chimney.
And may I say what a splendid chimney it is. One of the best! And, in addition to admiring your triumph of ventilative engineering - we’re here to see Mr Belfrage.
He’s off on his holidays.
Oh dear. Then we shall have to come back tomorrow.
You don’t have to come back at all.
F/X SOUND OF PROTEST OUTSIDE, IN THE FACTORY YARD.
No more accidents! / Fix the machines or we won’t go back to
work! / Strike! Strike!
Mr Townsend, I think you should take a look outside.
What?
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 18
It rather looks like the workers are revolting!
SCENE 9. EXT. FACTORY YARD
F/X GENERAL COMMOTION FROM WORKERS.
We’ll not work at faulty machines! / Justice for Stephen Gibson! / We’ll have no more accidents!
F/X DOOR OPENS, TOWNSEND STEPS OUT.
Brewster? Why aren’t you back at work?
We had an emergency ballot, and we agreed, we’re not touching those machines until you’ve had them checked out.
I didn’t realise you were the union’s fugleman.
Did you know this factory has more accidents than any other in Lancashire?
Really? Who told you this?
(OFF) I did.
Helpful lady, Miss Stretton. Got her heart in the right place.
I have corresponded with unions across the county. They keep such records, and no institution can boast as many accidents as this!
If that’s true, it’s because you lot can’t keep your minds on the job! There’s nowt wrong with that machinery!
Ah, but those are our terms. We want the site checked by an independent engineer or we go on strike. No man is going back to work in this factory until we know for sure that it’s safe!
F/X THE WORKERS LOUDLY AGREE AND APPLAUD.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 19
SCENE 10. INT. STRETTON’S HOUSE (LIVING ROOM)
F/X DOCTOR AND EVELYN HAVING TEA WITH STRETTON (50S, UPPER
CLASS, IRRITABLE).
How thoroughly dismal.
The accident, Mr Stretton? Or the strike?
Oh, both, both, Miss Smythe. But I fear it’s typical of this town.
Ackleton? Oh, it has its charm and its... vibrant atmosphere. The beating heart of the industrial revolution!
I’m trying to convince the party to let me stand somewhere in Kent next time. Clara has no chance of finding a suitable husband here, none at all.
F/X FRONT DOOR CLOSES.
I imagine that’s her now.
You should be proud of her. She’s only acting with the best of intentions.
When you attend my funeral, please tell that to your fellow mourners — I’m sure they’1ll find it of great comfort.
F/X DOOR OPENS, CLARA ENTERS.
Father — have you heard about the accident?
Indeed, I have heard altogether too much.
Well the workers have decided to down tools until there’s been an independent safety inspection.
And they receive a little extra in their wages, no doubt.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 20
You do them a disservice. This is entirely about safety.
I must admit, Mr Stretton, they do have my sympathies.
Yes, an employer does bear a responsibility to his workers. Their welfare is subject to his conduct, and if he doesn’t want that responsibility, then he shouldn’t be an employer.
I’m glad you think so, because I was hoping you could help.
Oh. Really?
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 2]
SCENE 11. INT. FACTORY FLOOR
F/X FADE UP. DOCTOR TINKERS AROUND INSIDE A LARGE PIECE OF
MACHINERY.
We said we wanted an expert.
Mr Stretton has vouched for Dr Smith’s credentials. I don’t see why I need look any further afield.
Brewster, I can assure you of my impartiality. All that matters to me is that the events of this morning aren’t repeated.
F/X DOCTOR SETS MACHINE RUNNING.
Rotary mechanism seems to be in good working order, but this piston arm’s coming out of lock as it travels back.
That doesn’t prove anything. There’s never been an injury at this machine.
Yes.. I’m sure you’d have caught this yourself during routine maintenance. Do you have a replacement for this piston?
In the cellar. Brewster?
Why do I have to get it?
Because I am in charge and it is your job to do as I Say.
Oh. Yeah. But this doesn’t count as returning to work, okay?
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 22
SCENE 12. EXT. STREETS
F/X EVELYN AND CLARA WALK ALONG.
I hope I haven’t put the Doctor in an awkward situation.
Oh, I wouldn’t worry about that. Awkward situations are the Doctor’s bread and butter.
I wouldn’t want to jeopardise his business with Mr Belfrage.
What type of man is he, this Mr Belfrage?

Well, Father was the one who brought him here. Initially Father spoke of him as a possible match for me, but, well, we both found him peculiarly abrasive and Father didn’t really want an industrialist in the family if he could help it. Mr Belfrage is what is known as a ‘self-made man’, you see.
He seems popular in the town.
Well, of course, he revived the industry. But I fear his interest might suddenly wane, and then where will we be?
F/X EVELYN AND CLARA REACH CLARA’S HOUSE, ENTER.
Where indeed? (BEAT) Please, don’t mention this to him — but I gather you’ve met Thomas Brewster, is that right?
Oh yes. A curious young man — bold for someone of his station.
You could say that. He was a sort of apprentice to the Doctor.
Gracious! He must have rare talents indeed for someone like the Doctor to confer such status on someone from his background.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 23
Yes. But it didn’t work out. The Doctor was all for leaving him at the first opportunity, but I convinced the Doctor he deserved a new start. Otherwise he might slip back into bad habits.
Do you feel there’s a danger of that with Mr Brewster?

I’m afraid so. We found a position for Brewster here and, without mentioning it to him, decided to stay in town for a few days, to see how he settled in. My idea, not the Doctor's. But then the Doctor began to develop suspicions about Mr Belfrage and his factory...
Suspicions?
Let’s just say there may be more to Mr Belfrage than meets the eye...
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 24
SCENE 13. INT. CELLAR
F/X FOOTSTEPS ON STONE FLOOR. BREWSTER STARTS RUMMAGING
THROUGH BOXES AND DRAWERS OF METAL JUNK.
Four-inch piston, four-inch piston, where are you? Bolts, yoke nuts, screws, spanners...
F/X DISTANT METALLIC CLANG.
Hello? Who’s there? (FINDS) Ah. Four-inch pistons. Got you!
F/X BREWSTER WALKS AWAY. AND THEN, VERY CLOSE TO THE
LISTENER, WE HEAR ONE, HUNGRY WORD:
Flesh.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 25
SCENE 14. INT. FACTORY FLOOR
F/X DOCTOR RUNNING TESTS ON ANOTHER MACHINE.
This is the machine Mr Gibson was working at this morning?
Aye. So what does listening to it with a stethoscope tell you?
It’s in perfect working order. Keep it well-oiled, replace all moving parts regularly, and it should give you years of steam- driven pleasure.
I knew it! It’s the men that are at fault, not the machines.
F/X MACHINE TURNED OFF.
Well, perhaps they need better training -
They need to keep their minds on the job is what they need. I mean, look at Brewster — how long’s he been gone?
Almost an hour. I wonder if he’s all right.
F/X BREWSTER RETURNS.
Speak of the devil. Where have you been?
I got the piston you needed.
And how did you spend the rest of your holiday?
I’m sorry, I... got lost.
Lost? How could you get lost in the cellar?
Hey, it’s like a maze down there, it’s pitch dark, and there’s so much junk lying about, you can never find anything.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 26
Sounds like a spot of spring cleaning may be in order? Thank you for finding this, Brewster. I’ve finished the inspection.
And?
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 27
SCENE 15. EXT. FACTORY YARD
F/X FADE UP. DOCTOR ADDRESSING CROWD.
I can assure you all that the machinery is safe. So long as you are vigilant and take care, you should come to no harm.
What? / I don’t like this. / I was sure he’d find something.
You heard him. So you can all get back to work!
No chance. / You’re joking, aren’t you? / You can’t be asking us to go back in there after what happened!
F/X DOCTOR TRIES TO REGAIN ATTENTION.
But if you do notice anything out of the ordinary, anything at all, you are to report it to me at once.
You just couldn’t bear to help me, could you?
(LOW) Brewster, the machines are working perfectly, you saw that. What am I supposed to say?
Now, gents, we’ve lost most of this morning, so if you’d care
to get back to your workplaces —
No.
No?
We’re not going back to work. (TO CROWD) Are we?
F/X CROWD SAYS ‘NO!’
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 28
SCENE 16. INT. STEPHEN’S HOUSE
F/X STEPHEN IS IN BED, BREWSTER IS WITH HIM. NOT IN BED WITH
HIM. AT HIS BEDSIDE. JUST TO MAKE THAT CLEAR.
There’s ways of going about these things, Brewster. Principles. You shouldn’t ask for more after they’ve agreed to your terms.
The men won’t go back in unless they get something in return.
I should be out there, this is my — (job)
F/X KNOCK AT DOOR.
Yes?
F/X CLARA ENTERS.
Mr Gibson — how are you?
Not too bad, considering.
I thought you should know. Mr Belfrage has just returned to Ackleton.
Good. Take me to him.
Oh, but Mr Gibson — you should be resting.
I’1l rest a lot easier when this is all sorted out.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 29
SCENE 17. INT. BELFRAGE’S OFFICE
F/X FURIOUS KNOCKING AT DOOR.
Yes? Come in?
F/X TOWNSEND ENTERS.
Mr Belfrage! What are we going to do about the strike, sir?
Oh, there’s a strike? I thought it was rather quiet. Assumed it was some religious holiday or other.
No sir. There was an accident this morning and Stephen Gibson, he lost three fingers.
How sad. Send his family some cooked meat and alcohol by way of an apology.
He doesn’t have a family. His wife died childless sixteen years ago.
Well, then just send enough for one.
I got an independent engineer to assess the condition of the machinery, he said there was nothing wrong — but now the workers are demanding shorter hours and more rest-breaks.
Right. (BEAT) That all sounds perfectly reasonable. Give them what they want and let’s have an end to it.
What?
Put together a new schedule, could you? I have a reception to
prepare for. Which do you think - bow-tie or four-in-hand?
But sir —
F/X BELFRAGE LEAVES THE OFFICE.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 30
SCENE 18. EXT. STREET
F/X DOCTOR AND EVELYN WALKING. EVENING BIRDSONG.
There really was nothing wrong with the machinery?
Not that I could find. Mr Townsend seems to run a pretty tight ship.
So you think the accident was Stephen’s fault?
Accidents will happen. However, there’s also the small matter of this device.
Ah. The item you stole from Mr Belfrage’s office?
Stole? I prefer to think of it as gathering evidence.
What does it do?
I don’t know. I’ve tried pressing the buttons, but other than making some bleeping noises — (F/X: SMALL, HI-TECH BLEEPING NOISES) — nothing seems to happen.
Maybe it’s a musical instrument?
Perhaps. Only one person to ask.
F/X FOOTSTEPS WALKING PAST.
Mr Belfrage!
Indeed.
No, Doctor. Look — Mr Belfrage. He’s come back. I recognise him from the painting in his office.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 31
Interesting that he should choose this moment to return...
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 32
SCENE 19. EXT. FACTORY YARD
F/X BELFRAGE WALKS OUT.
He’s in there now. / Bet we get nothing out of him. / Look, he’s coming out.
Ah, Gibson, isn’t it? Shouldn’t you be recuperating?
Not until I know that every man here [has the —]
I’ve agreed to everything. Shorter shifts, longer breaks.
For the same money?
I thought I might offer you slightly more. Business is rather good at the moment. It’s not going to be a problem, is it?
No, no. Not at all.
More money? / Blimey. / How much more, d’you think?
Now if you’ll excuse me.. no peace for the wicked.
F/X BELFRAGE LEAVES. TOWNSEND ENTERS YARD.
You heard the boss! You’re getting what you want, on one condition —
He didn’t mention any conditions!
On one condition — that you work a late shift tonight to catch up on the time lost today. We’ve got orders to fulfil.
Huh — all right. / Fair enough. / Suppose it’s worth it if we're getting more.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 33
Mr Gibson, where are you going?
Where do you think? Back to work.
You can’t go back to your old job, not now.
I’ve still got one good hand. I’11l do a stock-take in the cellar. Everybody’s always said that place needs a proper sorting-out.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 34
SCENE 20. INT. STRETTON HOUSE
F/X FADE UP. SMALL, POLITE GATHERING.
(WALKING OVER) Mr Stretton, delighted to see you, delighted. And may I say, this is a fabulous little bash!
Oh, please. It was no trouble at all to arrange it all at the drop of a hat when your message arrived at one o’clock this afternoon. How was Venice?
Even better than I’d heard. The Piazza San Marco, the Teatro La Fenice, the Rialto bridge...
You should’ve seen it in the good old days.
Indeed, but I’d say the faded glory lends it a certain...
Romantic melancholy?
Yes. I couldn’t have put it better myself.
Sorry — Mr Belfrage, this is Dr John Smith and Miss Evelyn Smythe.
Delighted.
Mr Stretton? I think one of your staff is trying to get your attention.
TUTS) Calamities in the kitchen, no doubt. Excuse me. (EXITS
We've been looking forward to meeting you, Mr Belfrage.
NERVOUSLY) Really? I hope it was worth the — (wait
Perhaps we could talk alone? In the study?
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 35
SCENE 21. INT. STUDY

STEPHEN: There’s ways of going about these things, Brewster. Principles. You shouldn’t ask for more after they’ve agreed to your terms.
BREWSTER: The men won’t go back in unless they get something in return.
STEPHEN: I should be out there, this is my — (job)
STEPHEN: Yes?
CLARA: Mr Gibson — how are you?
STEPHEN: Not too bad, considering.
CLARA: I thought you should know. Mr Belfrage has just returned to Ackleton.
STEPHEN: Good. Take me to him.
CLARA: Oh, but Mr Gibson — you should be resting.
STEPHEN: I’1l rest a lot easier when this is all sorted out.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 29
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 17. INT. BELFRAGE’S OFFICE
BELFRAGE: Yes? Come in?
TOWNSEND: Mr Belfrage! What are we going to do about the strike, sir?
BELFRAGE: Oh, there’s a strike? I thought it was rather quiet. Assumed it was some religious holiday or other.
TOWNSEND: No sir. There was an accident this morning and Stephen Gibson, he lost three fingers.
BELFRAGE: How sad. Send his family some cooked meat and alcohol by way of an apology.
TOWNSEND: He doesn’t have a family. His wife died childless sixteen years ago.
BELFRAGE: Well, then just send enough for one.
TOWNSEND: I got an independent engineer to assess the condition of the machinery, he said there was nothing wrong — but now the workers are demanding shorter hours and more rest-breaks.
BELFRAGE: Right. (BEAT) That all sounds perfectly reasonable. Give them what they want and let’s have an end to it.
TOWNSEND: What?
BELFRAGE: Put together a new schedule, could you? I have a reception to
BELFRAGE: prepare for. Which do you think - bow-tie or four-in-hand?
TOWNSEND: But sir —
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 30
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 18. EXT. STREET
EVELYN: There really was nothing wrong with the machinery?
DOCTOR: Not that I could find. Mr Townsend seems to run a pretty tight ship.
EVELYN: So you think the accident was Stephen’s fault?
DOCTOR: Accidents will happen. However, there’s also the small matter of this device.
EVELYN: Ah. The item you stole from Mr Belfrage’s office?
DOCTOR: Stole? I prefer to think of it as gathering evidence.
EVELYN: What does it do?
DOCTOR: I don’t know. I’ve tried pressing the buttons, but other than making some bleeping noises — (F/X: SMALL, HI-TECH BLEEPING NOISES) — nothing seems to happen.
EVELYN: Maybe it’s a musical instrument?
DOCTOR: Perhaps. Only one person to ask.
EVELYN: Mr Belfrage!
DOCTOR: Indeed.
EVELYN: No, Doctor. Look — Mr Belfrage. He’s come back. I recognise him from the painting in his office.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 31
DOCTOR: Interesting that he should choose this moment to return...
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 32
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 19. EXT. FACTORY YARD
WORKMEN: He’s in there now. / Bet we get nothing out of him. / Look, he’s coming out.
BELFRAGE: Ah, Gibson, isn’t it? Shouldn’t you be recuperating?
STEPHEN: Not until I know that every man here [has the —]
BELFRAGE: I’ve agreed to everything. Shorter shifts, longer breaks.
BREWSTER: For the same money?
BELFRAGE: I thought I might offer you slightly more. Business is rather good at the moment. It’s not going to be a problem, is it?
STEPHEN: No, no. Not at all.
WORKMEN: More money? / Blimey. / How much more, d’you think?
BELFRAGE: Now if you’ll excuse me.. no peace for the wicked.
TOWNSEND: You heard the boss! You’re getting what you want, on one condition —
BREWSTER: He didn’t mention any conditions!
TOWNSEND: On one condition — that you work a late shift tonight to catch up on the time lost today. We’ve got orders to fulfil.
WORKMEN: Huh — all right. / Fair enough. / Suppose it’s worth it if we're getting more.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 33
CLARA: Mr Gibson, where are you going?
STEPHEN: Where do you think? Back to work.
BREWSTER: You can’t go back to your old job, not now.
STEPHEN: I’ve still got one good hand. I’11l do a stock-take in the cellar. Everybody’s always said that place needs a proper sorting-out.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 34
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 20. INT. STRETTON HOUSE
BELFRAGE: (WALKING OVER) Mr Stretton, delighted to see you, delighted. And may I say, this is a fabulous little bash!
STRETTON: Oh, please. It was no trouble at all to arrange it all at the drop of a hat when your message arrived at one o’clock this afternoon. How was Venice?
BELFRAGE: Even better than I’d heard. The Piazza San Marco, the Teatro La Fenice, the Rialto bridge...
DOCTOR: You should’ve seen it in the good old days.
BELFRAGE: Indeed, but I’d say the faded glory lends it a certain...
DOCTOR: Romantic melancholy?
BELFRAGE: Yes. I couldn’t have put it better myself.
STRETTON: Sorry — Mr Belfrage, this is Dr John Smith and Miss Evelyn Smythe.
BELFRAGE: Delighted.
EVELYN: Mr Stretton? I think one of your staff is trying to get your attention.
EVELYN: We've been looking forward to meeting you, Mr Belfrage.
DOCTOR: Perhaps we could talk alone? In the study?
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 35
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 21. INT. STUDY
BELFRAGE: Who are you two anyway?
EVELYN: I’m Evelyn Smythe, and —
BELFRAGE: No, I can remember your names. What I’m not entirely clear about is who you are, and what you’re doing here.
DOCTOR: We’re a couple of people who found this in your office.
BELFRAGE: Oh. Great heavens. What is it?
DOCTOR: I’m not entirely sure myself.
BELFRAGE: Well, it’s not mine. I’ve never seen it before in my life!
STRETTON: What are you all doing lurking in here? You look like Roman conspirators.
BELFRAGE: Dr Smith wanted to ask my opinion on something he found at the factory.
STRETTON: Oh?
BELFRAGE: Show him. It really is a peculiar little thing. It’s not mine though.
DOCTOR: EY...
STRETTON: Let’s have a look then.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 36
BELFRAGE: And if you’ll excuse me, there are people out there I’d like to catch up with.
STRETTON: ‘Pon my soul.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 37
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 22. INT. FACTORY FLOOR
BREWSTER: Mr Townsend? You haven’t seen Mr Gibson, have you?
TOWNSEND: No, I haven’t. Why?
BREWSTER: No-one’s seen him since he went down to the cellar, and that was six hours ago.
TOWNSEND: Really? And you’re sure he didn’t just slip home while your back was turned?
BREWSTER: He might not have heard the whistle. Maybe I should go and get him?
TOWNSEND: All right, but don’t get yourself lost again. I need to lock
TOWNSEND: up.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004)
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 23. INT. STRETTON HOUSE
DOCTOR WHO: Page 38
STRETTON: Never seen anything like it in my life. Remarkable!
DOCTOR: Clara!
STRETTON: Oh, don’t show it to her — she’s fanciful enough as
CLARA: Oh, am I?
DOCTOR: Is Mr Belfrage around?
CLARA: No Father, I was about to tell you. Mr
CLARA: unwell. He’s gone home.
STRETTON: Gone home? Before dinner?
DOCTOR: Blast!
STRETTON: Profoundly vexing man — Doctor? Where are you going?
DOCTOR: Belfrage was
DOCTOR: (OFF) Sorry! Things to do, people to see!
STRETTON: it is.
STRETTON: feeling
STRETTON: Losing guests at a rate of knots here. I do hope it’s not a
STRETTON: reflection on the catering.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 39
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 24. INT. FACTORY CELLAR
BREWSTER: Stephen? You about? It’s home time! No clock down here, eh? Even if there was, you wouldn’t be able to — (see it)
BREWSTER: Stephen? Is that you? What are you doing over there?
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 40
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 25. EXT. STREET/INT. STATION OFFICE
DOCTOR: I can’t believe it. We had him in our grasp!
EVELYN: He did seem genuinely surprised when he saw that gadget.
DOCTOR: Maybe he was telling the truth — maybe it’s not his. That
DOCTOR: doesn’t mean I’m not right about him.
EVELYN: He’s not exactly acting like a man with nothing to hide.
DOCTOR: Yes... Train station! Let’s check in here...
DOCTOR: PLATFORM, OFF.
DOCTOR: Hello! Station master! Mr Belfrage — did he just...?
STATION MASTER: Aye, he’s just got on the Liverpool train.
EVELYN: What, that [one-?]
STATION MASTER: Yes, ma’am. That one.
STATION MASTER: ON
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 41
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 26. INT. FACTORY CELLAR
BREWSTER: Stephen? That you? It’s me. Brewster.
BREWSTER: (BEAT) Ohh, stuff this for a game of soldiers. I’m getting out of —
HUMANOID: Flesh.
BREWSTER: Whoaaa! Er —
HUMANOID: Fresh. Living. Flesh!
BREWSTER: Look, sorry to disturb you, whatever you are, only I was looking for this friend of mine... anyway, I can see he’s not here, so if you don’t mind —
BREWSTER: AND BONE. IT STRIKES THE NEAREST PILLAR, CAUSING CONSIDERABLE DAMAGE.
BREWSTER: Your arm.. there’s metal in it. Solid metal!
HUMANOID: Flesh!
BREWSTER: Hey, watch what you’re doing! You’1l bring the whole ceiling
BREWSTER: down on us if you keep —
HUMANOID: Flesh! Flesh! Flesh!
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 42

elements.text: PART TWO
GRAMS DOCTOR WHO THEME
SCENE 27. INT. LIVERPOOL STATION
F/X BACK ROOM. TARDIS LANDS, DOOR OPENS.
Aha! Told you I’d find a spot where nobody would notice us.
F/X DOCTOR AND EVELYN EXIT TARDIS, CLOSE DOOR, HEAD FOR
PLATFORM.
You know, Belfrage might not be coming here.
The station master said he’d bought a ticket for Liverpool.
He might have got off at an earlier stop.
True, but I don’t think he would’ve been expecting us to be here waiting for him - this is his train coming in now.
F/X STEAM TRAIN APPROACHING AS THEY STEP ONTO THE PLATFORM.
So we needn’t have bothered with all that running.
Fun though, wasn’t it?
No.
F/X TRAIN IS PULLING IN.
Keep a look-out for him getting off the train.
F/X TRAIN HAS STOPPED, PEOPLE POUR OUT.
There he is!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page
Aha!
F/X THEY DASH OVER TO SOMEBODY.
Mr Belfrage! Would you mind coming with -
What?
Oh.
Sorry, we thought you were someone else.
F/X MAN WALKS ON.
Sorry, I could have sworn — Oh there he is!
Where?
He just walked off the platform. Come on!
Oh, so now it’s fine to run, is it?
F/X THEY RUSH OFF IN PURSUIT.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 44
SCENE 28. INT. FACTORY CELLAR
F/X MEN MOVING RUBBLE.
(CALLS) Here he is! I’ve found him!
F/X EVERYONE RUSHES OVER, STARTS MOVING RUBBLE OFF BREWSTER.
He’s dead.
Brewster! Brewster, are you all right?
WEAKLY) Eh? (COUGHS
He’s alive.
What the hell happened to you, lad?
Can you save the questions for later? Help me lift him.
F/X STEPHEN HELPS BREWSTER OUT OF THE RUBBLE.
It’s alright, reckon I can stand —
Nothing broken?
No.
Then let’s get you some air. (ALOUD) C’mon, give us some room!
F/X THEY SHUFFLE UP THE STAIRS.
Stephen — listen. Listen!
I’m trying to get you out of here.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 45
Everyone’s got to get out of here. There’s something down there. Like a man, but taller... and with pipes and bolts and things sticking out of his skin.
Eh?
I’m not joking. He took a swipe at the pillar and it crumbled to pieces. That’s why the roof caved in, it’s not safe —
Calm down, lad. You’ve had a knock on the head. Come on.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 46
SCENE 29. EXT. LIVERPOOL STREET
F/X DOCTOR AND EVELYN WALKING ALONG, KEEPING LOW PROFILE.
Now our Mr Belfrage knows we’re following him.
And he doesn’t seem surprised that we’re here. Anyone who came from this planet, in this time, would be absolutely bamboozled by that.
So you’re right, he’s [not-] (BREAKING OFF) He’s stopped!
F/X DOCTOR AND EVELYN STOP TOO.
Don’t look at him. Pretend we’re having a conversation.
What about?
It doesn’t matter what it’s about, he can’t hear us.
Then we hardly need to pretend, do we?
Keep it up, this is going well.
Who’s he talking to?
Small, thin man in an overcoat - rather heavy for this time of year. He’s leading Belfrage towards a boarded-up shop. They’re going inside. Come on.
F/X THEY HURRY OVER TO THE BUILDING. CROSS TO:
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 47
SCENE 30. EXT. BESIDE SHOP
F/X They hurry UP TO BUILDING, try the door.
Locked. Hairpin?
There.
Thank you.
F/X DOCTOR FIDDLES WITH THE LOCK.
There’s something inside here.
It seems likely. Most buildings have something inside them.
No, I mean something odd. Touch the walls and you can feel a
buzzing and a.. tingly sort of taste in your mouth.
(TO LOCK) Oh for goodness’ sake, come on —
F/X DOCTOR BREAKS THE LOCK, DOOR OPENS. SHOP BELL JINGLES.
There goes the element of surprise.
Come on! Quickly!
F/X THEY PELT INSIDE.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 48
SCENE 31. INT. SHOP
F/X DOCTOR AND EVELYN RUSH IN TO FIND A SMALL SPACESHIP. ITS
ENGINES RISE IN PITCH — DOCTOR AND EVELYN SHOUT OVER THE NOISE.
What is it?
A space capsule belonging to the Doran, by the looks of it.
And that noise it’s making means...?
It means it’s just about to —
F/X DEMATERIALISATION NOISE. ENGINE NOISE VANISHES.
Leave.
Taking Belfrage with it.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 49
SCENE 32. EXT. YARD
F/X DOOR OPENS, STEPHEN HELPS BREWSTER OUT. CLARA RUNS OVER.
Mr Brewster!
Miss Stretton? What are you doing here?
I only just heard. I came to see if you were all right.
Yeah, I’m right as ninepence. Thanks to Stephen here.
You’re covered in cuts. Come back to the house with me and we’ll get those properly dressed.
Oh, I don’t want to trouble [you, Miss —]
Good heavens, you’ve just had a roof fall on your head, so please do as you’re told for once! Mr Gibson, how brave of you to rescue him when you — Mr Gibson, may I see your hand?
No.
But your fingers —
The extent of my injuries was exaggerated by gossip, Miss. My fingers are healing well.
I was there. I saw it.
So did I.
Your fingers were entirely severed. So how —?
Please, just forget it, it’s nothing. Now, I must help with the clearing up.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 50
F/X STEPHEN GOES BACK INSIDE.
Extraordinary. (BEAT) Come along, Mr Brewster. Time we got you tidied up too.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 51
SCENE 33. EXT. ALLEY
F/X DOOR OPENS, DOCTOR AND EVELYN EXIT.
— just want to take a look out the back.
Why?
To check they haven’t dumped any dangerous waste.
Ha! You’re an intergalactic caretaker.
It does feel like it, sometimes —
F/X BELFRAGE, LYING IN CORNER, GROANS.
Doctor! Beside the dustbins!
(GOING OVER) Ah, Mr Belfrage! We were worried we’d missed you.
(DAZED) What?
Looks like he’s been stunned.
Yes. I think you’ve been the victim of a double-cross, haven’t you?
F/X BELFRAGE SUDDENLY LEAPS UP.
Get back!
Steady on, we only want to know what you’re —
F/X BELFRAGE PUNCHES DOCTOR IN THE FACE.
Ow!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004)
There was no call for that!
You’1l have to catch me, coppers!
F/X BELFRAGE DASHES AWAY DOWN THE ALLEY.
Coppers?
Page 52
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 53
SCENE 34. INT. STRETTON HOUSE — DRAWING ROOM
F/X CLARA ENTERS.
There you are, Clara. I was worried, it’s almost three o’clock in the (SEES BREWSTER BEHIND) - what on Earth?
Pleasant to see you again, Mr Stretton.
Mr Brewster has suffered a terrible accident, Father.

I’m starting to feel we suffered a terrible accident the day we decided to come to this town. Come here, girl. (CLARA CROSSES OVER) (SOTTO) Clara, you cannot bring men home from the factory. I thank God that our guests have departed.
(SOTTO) Father, how can you be so inhuman? These are good, honest people —
(SOTTO) I don’t dispute their honesty or their goodness, but Clara, they are not our people. Do you wish to be like them?
(SOTTO) No, but —
(SOTTO) And yet all this contact you have with them can only serve to coarsen your own manners. I am concerned for you, and your future — if you carry on like this, what man will want you?

(SOTTO) Perhaps, a man who believes as I do that human suffering must always be alleviated whenever one possesses the means to do so. (ALOUD) Please sit down, Mr Brewster, and I shall fetch you some left-overs from the meal.
F/X CLARA STORMS OUT.
(BEAT) Nice house, sir.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 54
SCENE 35. EXT. ALLEY
F/X BELFRAGE RUNNING, THEN HE STOPS.
Damn!
F/X DOCTOR AND EVELYN RUNNING BEHIND HIM. THEY CATCH UP.
It’s a dead end, Mr Belfrage.
F/X BELFRAGE STARTS TRYING TO CLIMB THE WALL.
The wall’s too high. You’1l never be able to climb it.
Try and stop me!
I’m not sure we need to.
F/X BELFRAGE FALTERS AND FALLS HEAVILY TO THE GROUND.
Ow...
Now. Are you willing to stop being ridiculous?
F/X LASER PISTOL POWERING UP.
Oh no. Doctor. You’ve had your chance. Now — get out of my way or I’1l1 shoot.
You do realise the device you’re pointing at us isn’t a weapon, but is in fact a metallurgical spectrometer?
F/X METALLURGICAL SPECTROMETER POWERING DOWN.
All right. You got me. Are you going to do me for resisting
arrest as well?
We’re not the police.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 55
Oh good.
Which begs the question — what do you have to feel so guilty about?
If you’re not the police, I’m not telling you anything.
You will if you want my help — which you quite clearly need. What species are you?
(SIGHS) I’m Cahlian.

Cahlian. Ah! So you’re using a patch to pass for human. (TO EVELYN) They’re usually red-skinned, with scales and a tail. If he walked around here in his real appearance, you’d think Lucifer himself had dropped in.
So why are you scared about the police catching up with you?
I’ve been smuggling halite off-world.
Halite?
Rock salt.
I know what halite is.
Earth salt is considered a delicacy on certain worlds. And because Earth hasn’t yet made first interplanetary contact any trade in its goods is illegal.
I’ve got a stake in a salt mine in Northwich — I just take a small percentage, ask no questions. All minor league stuff.
Those trade rules exist for a reason.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 56
Look, if I ever get off this planet, I’m retiring. You don’t have to worry about that.
You’re stranded here?
Four years ago I parked my Astropod here and toddled off to Northwich, to pick up a consignment.
Why so far away?
I always land where nobody will recognise me, in case I get
seen. But the risk is leaving it unattended, you see. I got
back to find the thing had been stripped — starnav, orbital
stabiliser, cloak, comm system, even the hi-fi. And I'd left all my weapons on board. Stupid, I know, but I’d had so many smooth trips you can hardly blame me for getting complacent.
Surely you could have sent a distress signal?

I could, but then it’d be handcuffs, good morning judge and a lifetime on a penal asteroid. So I’ve been trying to get in contact with other offworlders who are popping by on the sly, so I can trade with them for spare parts for my ship.
Was that what you were doing with those people we saw you with?
No, they’d offered me a lift back to Cahlia — for a price. I wasn’t going to take them up on it, but when you showed up I thought it was better than getting nabbed by the fuzz.
Why weren’t you going to take them up on it?
I’ve got a cargo of salt to bring with me. My retirement plan! I know what that Doran lot are like — they’d have had the lot off me faster than you can say Miasimia Goria.
Well, I’m willing to offer you passage off the planet.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 57
You will?
But! You leave the salt behind.
What?
It’s either that, or we report you to the authorities.
(SIGHS) Yeah, all right. It’d be worth it just be on a planet without such a frequently condensational weather cycle.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 58
SCENE 36. INT. STRETTON’S HOUSE — DRAWING ROOM
F/X AS BEFORE.
(PICKING THINGS OFF MANTEL) Lovely porcelain pieces you’ve got here on the mantel, Mr Stretton, sir. Very fine.
Yes, and I'd be obliged if you’d replace them. Now, listen to me, Brewster.
I’m listening, sir. You’ve got my full attention.
My daughter seems to have taken a particular interest in you, has she not?
I wouldn’t know about that, since I don’t know how much interest she takes in everyone else.
Don’t dissemble, Brewster. You are not only aware of it, you take pleasure in it. It suits you well; you have ideas above your station. But Clara is a sensible girl.
Yeah, she must get it from her mother’s side of the family.

The thought of impropriety will not even have entered her mind. What she feels for you is pity, pure and simple. It does not concern me what she might do. What does concern me is what others may choose to believe.
You can’t control what people think, sir.
I can try. Brewster, you have no roots here. I could provide a substantial financial incentive for you to move on and never come into contact with Clara again.
(BEAT) What kind of incentive?
Fifty pounds.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 59
(WHISTLES) You were right. That’s pretty substantial.
You cannot put a price on a young lady’s reputation.
Oh, I don’t know. I think you just have.
F/X CLARA IS RETURNING.
Think on it, Brewster. The offer is for a limited time only.
Here we are. Goose, potatoes, carrots, and a slice of bride cake.
Much obliged to you, Miss Stretton.
If you are still hungry, there is a good deal more.
Yes, we lost three guests before dinner had even been served, hence we now have something of a surplus!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 60
SCENE 37. INT. LIVERPOOL STATION
F/X DOCTOR, EVELYN AND BELFRAGE ENTER THE BACK ROOM.
You parked your ship here, at the station? What sort of ship is it?
Something rather more advanced than — Oh.
What? Oh. Invisible shielding! Like it! The trick with these is to blink your eyes alternately, gives away the outline.
It was definitely here.
You mean the thing that we’re looking for isn’t invisible?
No. The TARDIS has gone.
It hasn’t just gone. It’s been stolen!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 61
SCENE 38. INT. STATION
F/X FADE UP. DOCTOR LEAVING AN OFFICE.
(OFF) Yes, thank you — I’m sure it was an honest mistake.
F/X CLOSES DOOR.
Well?

Apparently the TARDIS was standing next to some items waiting for transport. It was loaded onto a freight train for London. When it arrives they’ll have it sent straight up to Ackleton, but that won’t be until tomorrow.
And there won’t be a train back to Ackleton, not for another couple of hours.
Evelyn! How do you fancy exploring the nocturnal sights of 19th-century Liverpool? ‘The New York of Europe’?
Not a great deal.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 62
SCENE 39. INT. FACTORY FLOOR
F/X FADE UP. HARD AT WORK. CLARA AND BREWSTER ENTER.
Good morning, Mr Townsend.
(BEAT) Miss Stretton.
Mr Townsend.
Late again, Brewster. I should clock on before you miss any more of the day, if I were you.
I shall redeem your shortfall in wages from my own allowance, Mr Brewster.
Much obliged, Miss Stretton.
And to what do we owe the pleasure of your luminous presence?
Well, [I work —]
Miss Stretton, Brewster, not you.
I note that the factory floor is up and running.
Indeed. Why wouldn’t it be?
Due to the enormous hole in it, perhaps?
Most of the floor is entirely unaffected, rebuilding will take some weeks, and in the meantime we have orders to fulfil. We've already lost a good deal of time thanks to yesterday’s strike.
You’re lucky they haven’t gone on strike again today.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 63
The Lord has indeed smiled down upon me. Thank you for bringing that to my attention.
Have you checked the cellar for further structural problems?
(BEAT) I was just about to do so. Brewster!
What?
You're the only one who saw what happened last night. I need you to act as my guide in the underworld. You can be my Virgil!
Do I have to?
It does seem a little untoward to ask him to return so soon.
I'll be there to hold his hand, make sure he doesn’t take fright. Come on, Brewster.
(SIGHS) All right. But we get a gas lamp each, you got that?
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 64
SCENE 40. INT. TRAIN
F/X TRAIN CHUNTERING ALONG.
What a beautiful morning.
Yes, and a lovely part of the world. Was that what made you chose Ackleton, Mr Belfrage? The scenery?
Good grief, no. Why do you ask?
Most of the copper industry is in South Wales and Cornwall, it would seem more sensible for you to have based yourself there.
I needed to get the Astropod under cover as soon as possible, so I grabbed the most convenient empty property that I could find. The old Ackleton silk mill.
Ah yes, I heard you became the hero of the town.

The mill was the only major employer, when that died the town died. STRETTON: Yes, and I'd be obliged if you’d replace them. Now, listen to me, Brewster.
BREWSTER: I’m listening, sir. You’ve got my full attention.
STRETTON: My daughter seems to have taken a particular interest in you, has she not?
BREWSTER: I wouldn’t know about that, since I don’t know how much interest she takes in everyone else.
STRETTON: Don’t dissemble, Brewster. You are not only aware of it, you take pleasure in it. It suits you well; you have ideas above your station. But Clara is a sensible girl.
BREWSTER: Yeah, she must get it from her mother’s side of the family.
STRETTON: The thought of impropriety will not even have entered her mind. What she feels for you is pity, pure and simple. It does not concern me what she might do. What does concern me is what others may choose to believe.
BREWSTER: You can’t control what people think, sir.
STRETTON: I can try. Brewster, you have no roots here. I could provide a substantial financial incentive for you to move on and never come into contact with Clara again.
BREWSTER: (BEAT) What kind of incentive?
STRETTON: Fifty pounds.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 59
BREWSTER: (WHISTLES) You were right. That’s pretty substantial.
STRETTON: You cannot put a price on a young lady’s reputation.
BREWSTER: Oh, I don’t know. I think you just have.
STRETTON: Think on it, Brewster. The offer is for a limited time only.
CLARA: Here we are. Goose, potatoes, carrots, and a slice of bride cake.
BREWSTER: Much obliged to you, Miss Stretton.
CLARA: If you are still hungry, there is a good deal more.
STRETTON: Yes, we lost three guests before dinner had even been served, hence we now have something of a surplus!
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 60
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 37. INT. LIVERPOOL STATION
BELFRAGE: You parked your ship here, at the station? What sort of ship is it?
DOCTOR: Something rather more advanced than — Oh.
BELFRAGE: What? Oh. Invisible shielding! Like it! The trick with these is to blink your eyes alternately, gives away the outline.
EVELYN: It was definitely here.
BELFRAGE: You mean the thing that we’re looking for isn’t invisible?
EVELYN: No. The TARDIS has gone.
DOCTOR: It hasn’t just gone. It’s been stolen!
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 61
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 38. INT. STATION
DOCTOR: (OFF) Yes, thank you — I’m sure it was an honest mistake.
EVELYN: Well?
DOCTOR: Apparently the TARDIS was standing next to some items waiting for transport. It was loaded onto a freight train for London. When it arrives they’ll have it sent straight up to Ackleton, but that won’t be until tomorrow.
BELFRAGE: And there won’t be a train back to Ackleton, not for another couple of hours.
DOCTOR: Evelyn! How do you fancy exploring the nocturnal sights of 19th-century Liverpool? ‘The New York of Europe’?
EVELYN: Not a great deal.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 62
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 39. INT. FACTORY FLOOR
CLARA: Good morning, Mr Townsend.
TOWNSEND: (BEAT) Miss Stretton.
BREWSTER: Mr Townsend.
TOWNSEND: Late again, Brewster. I should clock on before you miss any more of the day, if I were you.
CLARA: I shall redeem your shortfall in wages from my own allowance, Mr Brewster.
BREWSTER: Much obliged, Miss Stretton.
TOWNSEND: And to what do we owe the pleasure of your luminous presence?
BREWSTER: Well, [I work —]
TOWNSEND: Miss Stretton, Brewster, not you.
CLARA: I note that the factory floor is up and running.
TOWNSEND: Indeed. Why wouldn’t it be?
CLARA: Due to the enormous hole in it, perhaps?
TOWNSEND: Most of the floor is entirely unaffected, rebuilding will take some weeks, and in the meantime we have orders to fulfil. We've already lost a good deal of time thanks to yesterday’s strike.
CLARA: You’re lucky they haven’t gone on strike again today.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 63
TOWNSEND: The Lord has indeed smiled down upon me. Thank you for bringing that to my attention.
CLARA: Have you checked the cellar for further structural problems?
TOWNSEND: (BEAT) I was just about to do so. Brewster!
BREWSTER: What?
TOWNSEND: You're the only one who saw what happened last night. I need you to act as my guide in the underworld. You can be my Virgil!
BREWSTER: Do I have to?
CLARA: It does seem a little untoward to ask him to return so soon.
TOWNSEND: I'll be there to hold his hand, make sure he doesn’t take fright. Come on, Brewster.
BREWSTER: (SIGHS) All right. But we get a gas lamp each, you got that?
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 64
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 40. INT. TRAIN
EVELYN: What a beautiful morning.
DOCTOR: Yes, and a lovely part of the world. Was that what made you chose Ackleton, Mr Belfrage? The scenery?
BELFRAGE: Good grief, no. Why do you ask?
DOCTOR: Most of the copper industry is in South Wales and Cornwall, it would seem more sensible for you to have based yourself there.
BELFRAGE: I needed to get the Astropod under cover as soon as possible, so I grabbed the most convenient empty property that I could find. The old Ackleton silk mill.
EVELYN: Ah yes, I heard you became the hero of the town.
BELFRAGE: The mill was the only major employer, when that died the town died. Stretton had just become the MP, and when he heard I was looking for property in the area, he convinced the land owner to give me the mill for a peppercorn rent. But I had to do something with it, and I just so happened to know a little trick with copper production which nobody else knew.
DOCTOR: Ah yes — extrusion. That was the first thing which tipped me off about you — it’s not supposed to be introduced in copper production for another thirty years.
BELFRAGE: It’s been a hell of a job keeping it secret, I can tell you.
EVELYN: Here we are. Ackleton.
BELFRAGE: Yeah, and for the last time, I hope.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 65
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 41. INT. FACTORY CELLAR
TOWNSEND: Now, we shall have to do this methodically. You know what ‘methodically’ means, Brewster?
BREWSTER: Yeah, we do it your way.
TOWNSEND: This is a floor plan of the cellar. We are here.
BREWSTER: No we’re not.
TOWNSEND: An auspicious beginning. What do you mean, no we’re not?
BREWSTER: Well, look, this room’s clearly bigger than that one. There are three pillars on the plan, I can see at least five from here.
TOWNSEND: Hm. The plan must be out of date.
BREWSTER: How long have you worked here, Mr Townsend?
TOWNSEND: The four years Mr Belfrage has been here, plus nineteen years when it was a silk mill. Why do you ask?
BREWSTER: It’s just you’re looking around the place like you’ve never
BREWSTER: seen this part of the cellar before.
TOWNSEND: It’s all changed since I was lowly enough to work down here.
BREWSTER: What’s this for then?
TOWNSEND: Er.. well it’s obviously pipes, and presumably...
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 66
BREWSTER: Cos it looks to me like a whole load of pipes and valves all stuck together, like some giant, fat spider hanging from the ceiling. And, what with my humble education, I can’t for the life of me work out what it does. Illuminate me, Mr Townsend.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 67
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 42. EXT. STATION
DOCTOR WHO: BELFRAGE. BEWILDERED CHATTER FROM PEOPLE IN FRONT OF THEM.
EVELYN: Doctor? There’s something going on in the booking office. Everyone’s stopped to look.
BELFRAGE: Oh, they’ve probably acquired a new hatstand and it’s probably a slightly unusual colour. The small-town mentality, you know.
DOCTOR: I think it’s rather more than that.
DOCTOR: BACKGROUND, DOZENS OF BITS OF MICRO-TECHNOLOGY WHIRR AND BLEEP QUIETLY.
EVELYN: Stationmaster? What on Earth is all this-?
STATION MASTER: I, uh, found these here items round the lintels when I opened up this morning. Lord alone knows what they all are, but I can tell you one thing. They’ve stuck to the walls like barnacles, there’s no scraping them off.
DOCTOR: Extraordinary. They seem to be made mostly from copper, but I can see evidence of diodes, microchips...
BELFRAGE: It looks like a computer has thrown up.
EVELYN: But what are they for? They must do something, surely?
DOCTOR: Most of them seem to be fine construction tools, but I can see surgeon’s tools, identity readers... and this is an atomic clock. But why all in one big chunk like this?
EVELYN: Oh. This thing’s just issued me with a train ticket.
DOCTOR: Well, this is a train station.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 68
EVELYN: Mr Belfrage, don’t wander off. Do you know anything about this?
BELFRAGE: Nothing to do with me, I’m afraid.
DOCTOR: Hmm. Well, I’m afraid your lift home is going to have to wait. This demands investigation.
EVELYN: (OFF) Doctor! There’s more of it downstairs, in the cellar.
DOCTOR: Right. Come on, Mr Belfrage.
STATION MASTER: Hey! You can’t go down... oh, all right, please yourselves.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 69
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 43. INT. FACTORY FLOOR
CLARA: Mr Gibson.
STEPHEN: Miss Stretton.
CLARA: You operate your machine with great ease, considering the injury you suffered just yesterday.
STEPHEN: I thought I told you to forget it.
CLARA: I apologise for disregarding your wishes, but I must have an answer. How did your fingers come back?
STEPHEN: (LOW) It was not some deal with the devil, if that’s what you’re thinking.
CLARA: (LOW) Good heavens no.
STEPHEN: (LOW) It was last night, when I was stock-taking in the cellar. I don’t remember what happened... it was as if I'd fallen asleep whilst walking... then the next thing I heard was the ceiling collapsing on Brewster, and my fingers [were just
STEPHEN: =
CLARA: Oh good lord.
WORKMAN: (SCREAMING) My hand... it’s got my hand!
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 70
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 44. INT. FACTORY CELLAR
BREWSTER: What’s that?
TOWNSEND: The pipes. There’s something in the pipes.
TOWNSEND: ALONG WITH METALLIC NOISES. CONTINUES UNDER DIALOGUE.
BREWSTER: It’s moving. It’s going down that end. What is it?
TOWNSEND: A rat, I expect.
BREWSTER: No — the valves are pushing it along.
TOWNSEND: But who’s operating it? There’s no-one down here but you and me.
BREWSTER: I wouldn’t be so sure about that. (BEAT) Hey, I think it’s heading down.
TOWNSEND: There’s an outlet at the bottom. If it is a rat, get ready to kill it.
TOWNSEND: PIPE.
BREWSTER: Ugh!
TOWNSEND: Oh my — It’s a hand! A human hand!
BREWSTER: With a wedding ring. Ugh. What is all this for?
TOWNSEND: And more to the point, who built it without my knowledge?
BREWSTER: So all this wasn’t here the last time you were down here?
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 71
TOWNSEND: No. I, ah.. shall have to consult Mr Belfrage about this upon his return. Dispose of this — hand, please, there’s a lad.
BREWSTER: What?!?
TOWNSEND: And then we go back to work. Back to normal.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 72
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 45. INT. TRAIN STATION (CELLAR)
DOCTOR WHO: TINY MICRO-TECHNOLOGY NOISES ALL AROUND.
EVELYN: (CALLS) Doctor! They go on all the way through here.
DOCTOR: (COMING OVER) They’ve burrowed through the cellar wall. But from where?
BELFRAGE: Look — are those arms?!?
EVELYN: I believe they are! Tiny mechanical arms, passing raw material along the tunnel, through the cellar and...
DOCTOR: Up the way we came. Yes — they’re building more of themselves. Using a large quantity of copper. Any ideas where they might be getting that? Belfrage?
BELFRAGE: (BEAT) Alright, alright, perhaps I do know something about it.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 73
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 46. INT. STRETTON HOUSE — DRAWING ROOM
STRETTON: Clara, you look pale, whatever’s the matter?
CLARA: Father. There’s been yet another accident at the factory — a man has lost a hand this time.
STRETTON: Oh dear. But what more can be done? The Doctor said —
CLARA: I don’t care what the Doctor said. I am going to write letters to everyone I can think of informing them of the disgrace that is that bedevilled factory.
CLARA: DIALOGUE; QUIETLY AT FIRST, THEN GRADUALLY LOUDER.
STRETTON: And what do you hope to achieve? Clara, at this rate you will have the place shut down, and then the town will be back where it was when we first arrived here. All my good work undone.
CLARA: Father, I don’t blame you for bringing Mr Belfrage here — I’m sure he seemed like a good [enough sort —]
STRETTON: Blame me? The whole town should [be grateful for —]
CLARA: Shh!
STRETTON: Good heavens, I thought I had raised you with better manners
STRETTON: [than to —]
CLARA: No — I mean, listen, father! Listen!
STRETTON: What on Earth is that?
CLARA: I think it came from the cellar.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 74
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 47. INT. STATION CELLAR/FACTORY CELLAR
BELFRAGE: I bought it off a Vislak loss-adjuster. What can I say, he had an honest face. Well, two honest faces, to be precise.
EVELYN: Sold what to you?
BELFRAGE: It’s an emergency device. He says his people carry them as standard. You see, it’s impossible to carry a spare for every part, and even if you knew how to build a new one —
DOCTOR: It’s no use if you’re on a planet which doesn’t have a sufficiently high level of technology.
BELFRAGE: Right. So this gizmo, it’s called a Catalyst. You’re meant to give it some examples of the best local tech to play with, and then it accelerates the technological level using its own data banks.
DOCTOR: You give it a machine, and it uses that machine to make more advanced machines, and so on, and so on.
BELFRAGE: Yeah, I dumped it in the cellar with a load of copper and other junk while I went off on the grand tour.
EVELYN: Left it to its own devices, as it were.
BELFRAGE: Seems to be working, anyway.
DOCTOR: Yes. It’s working only too well.
EVELYN: Why’s it digging its way into other cellars? This is the fifth one we’ve been through. It’s spreading all over the town.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 75
BELFRAGE: Search me. It didn’t say anything about this in the leaflet.
DOCTOR: Did it make the device I found in your office, I wonder?
EVELYN: Did you ever work out what that was?
DOCTOR: Some kind of tool. A medical implement, perhaps?
BELFRAGE: Maybe I got the settings wrong. I don’t know. Typical Vislak tech, never does what it’s supposed to. I mean, I’m not being racist, [but —]
EVELYN: Good.
BELFRAGE: Right, now — past this archway, we’re in the factory cellar.
DOCTOR: Then let’s find your gadget and turn it off before it spreads [any further —]
DOCTOR: FOOTSTEPS APPROACHING.
EVELYN: (LOW) What’s that?
DOCTOR: (LOW) Mr Belfrage?
BELFRAGE: (LOW) Don’t look at me.
EVELYN: (LOW) Oh good heavens.
DOCTOR: (LOW) It’s all right. I don’t think it saw us.
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 76
BELFRAGE: (LOW) Did it even have eyes? What was it? I saw metal, in its limbs. Pipes and bolts and —
DOCTOR: (LOW) I have no idea, but it was heading up to the factory floor. We have to get up there and evacuate everybody.
BELFRAGE: (LOW) We do?
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 77
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 48. INT. FACTORY FLOOR
STEPHEN: You heard the news then, Brewster?
BREWSTER: Er, I gathered, yeah. Another accident.
STEPHEN: And we can’t find the Doctor. They’ve taken James home, but I’m not sure he’1ll make it. If you see the Doctor, tell him.
BREWSTER: I will.
TOWNSEND: Brewster?
BREWSTER: Yes?
TOWNSEND: That sack you’re carrying. Is that the, er...
BREWSTER: The hand, sir? James’s hand? Is his severed hand in my sack, is that what you’re asking, sir?
TOWNSEND: (LOW) Keep your voice down. I told you to get rid of it. Give it to me.
BREWSTER: I don’t want to go spreading wild assertions, but when you look at those pipes down there and you think about all the accidents we’ve had, well it looks almost like someone’s collecting bits of people, doesn’t it?
TOWNSEND: Firstly, shut up; secondly, give me the sack; and thirdly, get back to work, or I will be the one giving you the sack.
BREWSTER: All right, Mr Townsend. Whatever you say.
TOWNSEND: Now [look sharp —]
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 78
DOCTOR WHO: CONSTERNATION AMONG WORKERS.
WORKMEN: What the — / Some kind of creature! / Look! What is it?
HUMANOID: Townsend.
TOWNSEND: Oh dear lord —
STEPHEN: Get back, lads!!! (RUSHING OVER) What is that creature-?
BREWSTER: (SHOUTS) It’s the thing I saw, the monster what brought the cellar down on me. It’s coming up through the hole in the floor!
HUMANOID: The part.
TOWNSEND: Wha — what —
BREWSTER: The hand, it wants the hand.
HUMANOID: And... Townsend.
TOWNSEND: (GRABBED BY HUMANOID) What-? No! No, get off me-!
HUMANOID: (RIPPING TOWNSEND APART) Townsend. Flesh. Fresh, living, flesh!
TOWNSEND: Nooooooo=-!!!!
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 79
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 49. INT. STRETTON CELLAR
DOCTOR WHO: FROM BEHIND A WALL.
STRETTON: Such a terrible noise! It’s not some new-fangled device for clothes-laundering, is it?
CLARA: I will ask Mary when she returns from shopping — but I’m sure she would have consulted us before buying something like that.
STRETTON: It appears — yes, it appears to be coming from behind the inner wall.
CLARA: Well, then — it must be something our neighbours have acquired.
STRETTON: It’s downright inconsiderate. I shall call on them and complain.
CLARA: Father, please be conciliatory.
STRETTON: I don’t see why I should be, [it’s —]
STRETTON: CRUNCH MENACINGLY.
CLARA: Good heavens!
STRETTON: And now it’s coming through the wall! Infernal machinery! Back! Back!!!
CLARA: Father, it’s getting closer. Father! Run!
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 80
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 50. INT. FACTORY FLOOR
HUMANOID: (OFF) Flesh! Fresh. Living. Flesh!
BREWSTER: It’s dragged him back down the cellar. (BEAT) Eurgh, don’t look!
STEPHEN: Maybe it’s on our Side.
BREWSTER: What?
STEPHEN: Well, it killed Townsend, didn’t it?
BREWSTER: You stick around and try to sign it up to the union if you like, but I’1ll pass. (ALOUD) I’m getting out of here. You lads with me?
BREWSTER: The door. Won’t open.
STEPHEN: Have you released the bolts?
BREWSTER: They weren’t on, it’s wedged shut.
STEPHEN: Get out the way and let me have a go.
STEPHEN: MACHINERY IS GETTING CLOSER AND WILDER.
STEPHEN: Come on...
BREWSTER: It’s no good, we’re locked in!
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 81
WORKMEN: What? Can’t we get out? / What’s the problem? / We’ve got to get away from that thing!
STEPHEN: Come on, stupid —
BREWSTER: Stephen —
STEPHEN: Brewster, if you just let me concentrate —
BREWSTER: Stephen, the machines! They’re running by themselves! —
BREWSTER: Yeah, and now they’re moving!
STEPHEN: But that’s impossible, they should be fixed to the floor.
BREWSTER: Not any more they’re not. It’s like — like they’re alive...
STEPHEN: They’re getting closer! What do they want? Brewster? What do they want?
STEPHEN: HIGHER, MADDER TEMPO.
BREWSTER: Isn’t it obvious? First they took a few fingers, then they
BREWSTER: took a hand... and now they’re coming for the rest of us!
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 82

elements.text: PART THREE
GRAMS DOCTOR WHO THEME
SCENE 51. FACTORY CORRIDOR
F/X DOCTOR, EVELYN AND BELFRAGE RUN UP THE STAIRS FROM THE
CELLAR. SOUNDS OF MACHINERY RUNNING AWAY ON FACTORY FLOOR
ABOVE.
No sign of the creature.
Well, there’s more than one way up to the factory floor.
Yes. — What’s going on up there?
F/X THEY OPEN THE DOOR TO THE FLOOR. CROSS TO:
REPRISE FROM SCENE 50:
They’re getting closer! What do they want? Brewster? What do they want?
F/X THE MACHINES ARE INDEED GETTING CLOSER, AND RUNNING AT A
HIGHER, MADDER TEMPO.
Isn’t it obvious? First they took a few fingers, then they
took a hand... and now they’re coming for the rest of us!
SCENE CONTINUES:
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 83
SCENE 52. INT. FACTORY FLOOR
F/X MEN PANICKING TO GET AWAY FROM THE ADVANCING MACHINERY.
Get back, you lot! / Can’t go any further! / Try the door again! / We’re done for!
(FROM OFF) Evelyn! Be careful!
What-?
(RUSHING FORWARD) Brewster! Are you all right?
Miss Smythe! Doctor!
What on Earth’s been happening here?
We can’t get out — the doors are locked and the machines just started moving around and eating people and there’s this thing in the cellar, like a man made out of pipes —
F/X MACHINE LURCHES FORWARD, MENACINGLY.
You men — move away from the machines!
Yeah, where to-?!?
This way. We can escape through the cellars.
Didn’t you just hear me? There’s a monster down there!
We know. But at the moment it seems to be otherwise occupied.
Please! Let’s not stand around discussing the matter when we could be getting out of here!
(BEAT) All right. (CALLS) Stephen!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 84
(OFF) There’s nothing we can do, I can’t get the door —
(CALLS) Forget the door! We’re going out through the cellar!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 85
SCENE 53. INT. STRETTON HOUSE — HALLWAY
F/X FADE UP. STRETTON AND CLARA RUSHING INTO THE HALLWAY FROM
CELLAR. MACHINERY CAN STILL BE HEARD FROM CELLAR. STRETTON SLAMS THE CELLAR DOOR SHUT, DRAWING BOLTS, THROUGH:
The Doctor is an engineer, he may be able to help. Or explain to us what is happening.
I have sealed the cellar. You go, Clara — I will remain here.
No, Father — you must come too, it isn’t safe.
This is my house, and I shall not abandon it to be taken over by an abomination of pistons and gears.
Please, don’t be [so obstinate —]
A man’s home is his castle. Even in the face of... an engine at the door!
F/X MACHINERY TEARS THROUGH THE FLOOR AND MENACES THEM. THEY
ARE BOTH STARTLED.
Now they’re coming through the floor! Father, we must go!
Upstairs!
F/X THEY ESCAPE UPSTAIRS.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 86
SCENE 54. INT. FACTORY CELLAR
F/X A FEW DOZEN MEN HURRYING THROUGH, FOLLOWING THE DOCTOR.
Follow me, everyone. Mr Belfrage — which way?
I can’t remember, it all looks completely different.
How about through that door over there?
Yes, I think you [might be —]
F/X EVELYN OPENS THE DOOR, CLANKING MACHINERY BEYOND. SHE
CLOSES IT.
It’s spreading down here.
What’s spreading?
Whatever it is that is making your machinery run amok.
There isn’t meant to be any machinery down here. This is just
for storage.
Then it is worse than I had feared.
How?
It means the machinery itself is building more machinery.
F/X CRUNCH AS THE MACHINERY PUNCHES THROUGH THE DOOR.
Look out!
It knows we’re down here!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 87
It killed all those men up there... and now it’s coming after us too! We’re trapped!
Nonsense, we'll find the way out. (BEAT) Fingers crossed!
F/X THEY ALL TROOP OFF.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 8&
SCENE 55. INT. STRETTON HOUSE — LANDING
F/X CLARA AND STRETTON RUN UPSTAIRS. LOUD, METHODICAL CLANK
ECHOES UP THE STAIRS.
Father, it’s following us!

From the day I first set eyes on one of those vile machines, I knew they would be the end of us. But this town had got rid of them, and I helped to bring them back — for the sake of my own miserable career.
For the sake of the town. You brought life back to this place.
And now I have brought death. This is my punishment. I have lived by machines and now I am to die by them.
F/X MACHINERY TEARS THROUGH THE FLOOR NEARBY.
Father, don’t just stand there! Into the bedroom!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 89
SCENE 56. INT. STRETTON HOUSE — BEDROOM
F/X DOOR SLAMMING SHUT ON ADVANCING MACHINERY.
I am sorry that I have brought this upon you. You have tried to protect man from the machines... which is more than I ever
did.
The window, Father. We can still get away!
Er.. yes. The window.
F/X CLARA OPENS A SASH WINDOW.
You must go first, my dear. Be careful.
F/X CLARA STARTS TO CLIMB OUT.
Do as I do — hang from the ledge and allow yourself to drop.
It shortens the distance one has to fall quite considerably.
Always so practical.
F/X CLARA ALLOWS HERSELF TO DROP.
(OFF) Now follow, quickly.
Goodbye, Clara. Forgive me.
F/X STRETTON CLOSES THE WINDOW, CUTTING OFF CLARA’S NEXT
(OFF) No!
F/X DOOR BURSTS OPEN. THE CLANK OF MACHINERY GETS LOUDER.
(SINGS QUIETLY, RESOLUTELY, TEARFUL) ‘And did the countenance divine, shine forth upon our clouded hills, and was Jerusalem builded here, among these dark Satanic mills —’
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 90
SCENE 57. INT. FACTORY CELLAR
(RUNNING UP) Aha!
You’ve found a way out?
Through the hole in the wall and straight up the stairs.
We need someone to lead the way. I nominate... me.
So you’ll be the one who gets out first.
Well, quite. I’m not a complete idiot.
