STRETTON: Don’t listen to her. She is in thrall to the machines. (SINGS SOFTLY) ‘And was the Holy son of god, on England’s pleasant pastures seen?’ (HUMS TO HIMSELF)
EVELYN: Clara, everyone’s in terrible danger — we have to get away.
CLARA: Father?
STRETTON: You’1l be safe here. With me. My daughter. My flesh and blood.
CLARA: I can’t leave him, Miss Smythe.
EVELYN: (SIGHS) I’1l1 come back for you. But don’t trust him.
STRETTON: My darling daughter. Please, sit beside me on the grass.
CLARA: Father, what — (happened here)
STRETTON: Shhh, my dear. Listen. Listen. Can’t you hear it?
CLARA: Hear what?
STRETTON: The death knell of the industrial revolution...
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 117
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 70. INT. FACTORY
DOCTOR WHO: AS THEY FIGHT THEIR WAY THROUGH, SQUIRTING GLUE GUNS.
DOCTOR: Brewster! Belfrage! Are you still with me?
BREWSTER: Just about, Doctor.
BELFRAGE: My office is through there, which means -
BREWSTER: We've got our work cut out. You sure there isn’t another way round? What about through here?
BELFRAGE: More of them! Brewster, shut that door!
DOCTOR: No, wait! Look there, in the centre. What is that?
BELFRAGE: Don’t ask me, I’ve never seen it before.
BREWSTER: Looks like a big egg or something. Look out, Doctor!
DOCTOR: What - whoa! No! You! Don’t!
DOCTOR: BREWSTER SLAMS IRON POLE INTO IT.
DOCTOR: Thank you.
BREWSTER: Glad to be of service. Told you an iron bar would do the trick!
BELFRAGE: Whatever laid that egg, it wasn’t anything to do with the Catalyst.
DOCTOR: You’re sure?
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 118
BELFRAGE: Totally sure. Look at it. It’s organic.
BREWSTER: Careful, Doctor. Stay back.
DOCTOR: The machinery’s defending it.. an instinctive response!
BREWSTER: I don’t think it likes us being here.
DOCTOR: I’m sure it doesn’t. If we can put it out of action, all will stop. Probably.
BELFRAGE: Well yes, but you’ll never get near it. At least, not in piece.
DOCTOR: All right — let’s go.
BELFRAGE: I still don’t know how we’re going to get to my office.
BELFRAGE: way’s totally blocked.
DOCTOR: We’ll see about that.
BREWSTER: Doctor, look out — the floor’s giving way!
DOCTOR: Whoaaa —
BREWSTER: Doctor!
BREWSTER: this
BREWSTER: one
BREWSTER: The
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 119
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 71. EXT. STREET
EVELYN: Mr Gibson! Stephen! I’m glad you’re still here.
STEPHEN: Mrs Smythe! Where did you go? Where’s Clara?
EVELYN: She’s not coming.
STEPHEN: Why not?
EVELYN: I can’t explain. How’s it going? Are people leaving?
STEPHEN: Most of them. There are a few stubborn ones, but they’1l1 see the light in time. But Miss Stretton —
EVELYN: I’1l deal with her. Right now we need to —
STEPHEN: They’re coming back into town. Why are they coming back?
HUMANOID: (OFF) Flesh! Flesh! Flesh!
EVELYN: I think they’re running away from that.
STEPHEN: But we killed it. The train smashed it to pieces.
EVELYN: You may have seen off one of them... but there’s two of them
EVELYN: now!
STEPHEN: How many are there?
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 120
EVELYN: I don’t think anyone’s planning on sticking around to keep count.
EVELYN: OUT.
HUMANOID: (OFF) Fresh! Flesh!
STEPHEN: Where are all they coming from?
EVELYN: Isn’t it obvious? That one. Look. Don’t you recognise the face?
STEPHEN: What? But isn’t that... Mrs Coulton?
EVELYN: Exactly. They’re making themselves out of bits of us! To them we’re nothing but a walking mass of... spare parts!
STEPHEN: We might still be able to get out. If we head through the rail tunnel, after that it’s open moorland —
EVELYN: It’s worth a try — but I think they may have already be one step ahead of us.
EVELYN: COLLAPSES. SCREAMS.
STEPHEN: The tunnel. They’ve sealed off the tunnel. There’s no way out of Ackleton!
EVELYN: Which means, Mr Gibson, that very soon everyone in the town will be dead!
DOCTOR WHO: INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 12]

elements.text: PART FOUR
GRAMS DOCTOR WHO THEME
SCENE 72. INT. FACTORY FLOOR
F/X MACHINERY CLANKING AROUND BREWSTER AND BELFRAGE.
(CALLING BELOW) Doctor? Doctor!
Brewster, be careful — the floor’s not stable. The machines must have been cutting across it.
Yeah, I know, and I know the cellar’s crawling with them and they’11 kill the Doctor if we don’t get him out of there!
Don’t you see? This is perfect. We needed to lose him anyway.
But we can’t just leave him to die.
(OFF) Well, quite.
(SOTTO) You had to speak too soon, didn’t you? You had to do Lt!
(CALLS) Doctor! Are you all right?
(OFF) More or less.
We can’t get down to you, I’m afraid!
(OFF) I’1ll try to get up.
No, you’ll never make it. You get out through the cellars, we'll get the control watchermakallit.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 122
(OFF) I suppose I don’t have any choice.
You want me to throw you down an iron bar?
(OFF) No! No! No, thank you — I’ve still got some adhesive, I'll be fine.
We’re going to head for the office, try and find a way through. It’s getting worse up here.
(OFF) All right. Good luck!
F/X DOCTOR LEAVES. BREWSTER AND BELFRAGE STAND.
Do you think he bought it?
Does it matter? I just wanted him to stop shouting at me and go away, and he has. Shall we go?
But there’s no way through, the machines -
Ah, but I was lying when I said this was the only way. If we climb outside, we should be edge along and in through one of the windows. Do you think you’re up to it?
Oh yeah. I’ve done that sort of thing once or twice before...
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 123
SCENE 73. EXT. STREET
F/X HUMANOIDS ADVANCING ON TOWNSPEOPLE.
(OFF) Fresh! Flesh! Living! Flesh! Fresh! [ETC]
CRIES OF FEAR AND TERROR
Those creatures are blocking every way out of town.
Then we’re trapped. (BEAT) Except...
What?
I was told by... er, someone, that the creatures can’t harm us in the countryside. It doesn’t make sense, but -
But we can’t reach the countryside, the tunnel [is closed. ]
No. But we may be able to get to the next best thing. Stephen,
get everyone to follow me.
If you say so. (CALLS) This way! Everyone, this way!
F/X MASS EXIT OF TOWNSPEOPLE.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 124
SCENE 74. EXT. WINDOW LEDGE/INT. UPPER FLOOR OF FACTORY
F/X BELFRAGE AND BREWSTER ARE EDGING ALONG A WINDOW LEDGE.
You alright there, Mr Belfrage?
I’m fine, I just don’t have a head for heights, that’s all.
Tip for you, don’t look down. I said don’t look down!
Remind me, whose idea was this?
Nearly there, take my hand, now — get a grip of the drainpipe, it should hold your weight, just about. That’s it.
Now what-?
Hang on, while I just —
F/X WINDOW SMASHES. BELFRAGE AND BREWSTER SCRAMBLE THROUGH
INTO UPPER FLOOR.
And we're in. (BEAT) Hey, what’s happened in here? Looks like the insides of a spaceship!
The Catalyst must’ve transformed the anteroom into a kind of airlock.
To stop the machines breaking into your office?
I think so.
So how do we get in?
By the look of it, a basic print and retinal scan job.
Well, see if it knows who’s boss.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 125
Nothing to lose, I suppose.
F/X BELFRAGE PRESSES A CONTROL. THE DOOR SCANS HIM. THEN IT
UNLOCKS.
Well, I’1ll be — It worked!
Must be our lucky day. Get in!
F/X THEY CROSS INTO:
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 126
SCENE 75. INT. BELFRAGE’S OFFICE
F/X DOOR CLOSED. BLEEPING TECH ALL AROUND.
(WHISTLE) Blimey. It’s like an Aladdin’s cave in here!
The Catalyst’s crammed the place with its technology.
I get it. It doesn’t know how to fight, so instead it’s been trying to hide itself away. Like it’s building a nest!
Trying to keep the controller safe.
So where is this thing then, boss?
In the bureau. Second drawer from the bottom.
F/X BREWSTER ATTEMPTING TO OPEN DRAWER.
It’s locked. Do you have the key?
The key? (PATTING POCKETS) I — I must have put it down somewhere -
Oh, never mind. (HEFTING IRON BAR) I got an iron bar for a picklock.
But — that’s genuine mahogany. I was going to take that with me!
Now that’s a shame.
F/X BREWSTER SMASHES THE BUREAU OPEN.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 127
SCENE 76. EXT. SITE OF STRETTON HOUSE
F/X EVELYN, STEPHEN AND OTHER TOWNSPEOPLE ARRIVE AT THE
NONEXISTENT HOUSE.
Evelyn!
(APPROACHING) Clara — have the creatures attacked you here?
No. No, they haven’t.
Nor will they.
I hope for all our sakes, Mr Stretton, that you are not mistaken. (CALLING) Everyone — gather round, on the lawn! Please, trust me — you’1l be perfectly safe!
F/X SEVERAL HUMANOIDS ARE APPROACHING.
Fresh! Flesh! Fresh! [ETC]
(ALOUD) Those creatures are but revenants of industry — what they fear most is the natural world. It stands to reason.
I’d rather have something slightly more concrete than that, but...
F/X HUMANOIDS STOP AT THE EDGE OF THE LAWN, HOWL WITH
FRUSTRATION. HUBBUB RUNS THROUGH CROWD.
We... cannot pass.
Well, it seems the proof is in the pudding!
Father did say we would be safe here.
Yes, he did. But how did you know, Mr Stretton?
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 128

Because nature saved me. (RAISES VOICE) I was without hope, at the mercy of the infernal engines. My home and all that I knew was being consumed by them. But the plants and the ground rose up, claimed the machines and saved my life. We have taken the wrong path. I have abetted the rise of the machines and I beg my soul’s forgiveness. We must all return to nature.
(APPROACHING) Beg pardon, sir, but what does that mean, returning to nature? Men have used machines of one kind or another to work the land for many a year — d’you mean us to live by our bare hands?
That is the will of God, Stephen. Trust in thy Lord, and he will show us the way.
You sound like a preacher, Mr Stretton.
My decision to enter politics was the product of arrogance; it led me to despoil God’s green Earth. But in the future, [I shall —]
F/X STRETTON IS INTERRUPTED BY GROUND CAVING IN NEARBY.
SOMEONE IS DIGGING THROUGH.
What in heaven’s name — Get back! EVELYN:
Something’s coming up through the ground.
Another of those demons? Or more machinery?
It cannot be. No infection may trespass upon this new Eden, this.. fortress built by nature for herself.
F/X SOIL MOVES ASIDE, DOCTOR EMERGES.
Hello. Hope you don’t mind me gatecrashing your garden party!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 129
SCENE 77. INT. BELFRAGE’S OFFICE
F/X BELFRAGE OPERATES A HANDHELD CONTROL, LIKE A SLIGHTLY
LARGER GAMEBOY.
That’s it? That’s what we came here for?
What were you expecting?
I dunno. Something bigger.
F/X BELFRAGE TURNS IT ON.
They could make it smaller, but you wouldn’t be able to press the buttons. Vislaks have fingers like sausages. Look, on the screen.
That’s a map of the town, isn’t it?
Yes - and the locations of everything the Catalyst has made. It’s listing a lot of stuff as ‘Location unknown’, which presumably means it’s either been stolen or destroyed...
So what’s left?
Well, fortunately it appears to have sealed off the part of the cellar where my ship’s hidden, and it looks like the parts I needed to repair it have come through. Result!
We’d better move then, hadn’t we? Before the machines get a hold of it.
It’s not just a question of getting there, I need long enough to repair the ship. Come on, this thing must have made some kind of weapon. (BEAT) Ah! Short-focus laser.
Some kind of gun?
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 130
Yes. One which we can use to turn that egg thing into a pile of smoking ash without us having to get anywhere near it.
Where is it?
In the cellars of the Red Lion.
Ah, great. We can have a cheeky half while we’re there!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 131]
SCENE 78. EXT. SITE OF STRETTON HOUSE
F/X EVELYN HELPS THE DOCTOR OUT OF THE HOLE.
(EFFORT) Come along, Mr Mole. Let’s get you out of your hole —
Yes, thank you, Evelyn. — (HE’S OUT)
Now. — What in heaven’s name were you doing underground?
(DUSTING HIMSELF DOWN) I was trying to find my way out of the cellars when I spotted an area totally clear of machinery. Made my way up the stairs and came out... wherever this is?
This used to be our house.
Clara — his coat is filthy. Take it from him.
What?
His coat. Take it.
Please, don’t fuss. — Your house? Really? It’s gone a bit... al fresco.
It seems it just collapsed into the ground and this little
patch of grass and trees appeared in its place.
How extraordinary! Did anyone see this happen?
I saw it. A miracle amidst the chaos.
Indeed.
F/X DOCTOR WALKS OVER TO THE HUMANOIDS, WHO ARE GROWLING.
Hello there!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 132
We wait.
So I see. Patience is a virtue!
They’ve been standing there for several minutes, like vampires who haven’t been invited in.

An apposite analogy. But vampires’ limitations are extremely rare, possibly unique. These creatures were built from human flesh. There’s no physical reason why they shouldn’t be able to stroll up to us. So why don’t they?
(OFF) They are polluted.
F/X DOCTOR TURNS, WALKS TOWARDS STRETTON.
Why do you say that, Mr Stretton?
They are an unholy melding of man and machine. They are not fit for the world as the Lord made it. Clara — take his coat.
Doctor —
Just a moment, Clara — this isn’t the world as God made it. This morning, it was a house!
Its transformation was an act of God.
I’m afraid not. It was an act of a small-scale terrain enhancer. You can tell, there’s a slight smell like aniseed in the air. Those are the nanites getting up your nose.
I don’t understand your words, Doctor.
No, but I think your father does.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 133
I’m afraid not. This was an act of God. How dare you claim that some vile, souless artefact was responsible.
You're lying, Mr Stretton, but I think your sentiments are genuine. It must appal you to be even more ‘polluted’ than the creatures you despise.
What?
If I cut you, you will not bleed; and if I punch you on the nose, I think you will go ‘clang’.
F/X DOCTOR PUNCHES STRETTON ON THE NOSE, HE GOES ‘THONGG’.
MURMURS THROUGH CROWD.
What? / He was right! / Is that really Stretton?
That was more of a ‘thongg’.
(NURSING BRUISED HAND) Yes, well it’s not an exact science. Ow!!!
Father? What has happened to you?
I’m afraid that’s not your father, Miss Stretton.
I told you he seemed different.
Ignore them, Clara. They are the servants of evil.
On the contrary. You’re not Mr Stretton, though you have two things in common with him. One is that you wear the same face, and the other...
Let go of my shirt, sir!
F/X DOCTOR TEARS STRETTON’S SHIRT OPEN. GASPS FROM CROWD.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 134
Is that you are a hypocrite. Stretton never admitted that he
abhorred the industry he brought back to the town, but if you talked to him it was quite obvious. Conversely, you claim to
hate technology, but you yourself are half-machine!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 135
SCENE 79. INT. PUB
F/X SALOON DOORS. BELFRAGE AND BREWSTER ENTER. MACHINES GOING
MAD.
Good grief. Pipes and pipes! It’s like a plumber’s nightmare.
So much for that cheeky half. You said the pub would be clear!
The display on the Catalyst said it was.
That egg thing that’s directing the machines — it knows we’re after it. It’s trying to stop us getting to this laser. Maybe it would be better if we just found the Doctor — (and)
I’m not losing my cargo, Brewster — and that means no Doctor. That’s what we agreed.
I know, but considering what we’re up against, [you —]
Do you want the tech the Catalyst has generated or not?
Well, yeah.
Then shut up and help me figure out how we’re gonna get past these things.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 136
SCENE 80. EXT. SITE OF STRETTON HOUSE
F/X AS BEFORE. MURMURS AMONG CROWD.
This body is a means to an end, nothing more.
I saw the device in the heart of the factory, manipulating the machines. That’s your true form, isn’t it? Stretton is nothing more than your puppet!
Oh, no, no! Father!

I’m sorry, Clara. Your father is dead. (TO STRETTON) This creature has recreated his body using technology made by Belfrage’s Catalyst, technology he stole. Just like he used the Catalyst’s technology to create these monsters, and to turn Stretton’s house into a grassy hillock.

I despise myself for using these vile devices, but they were too useful — and my mission too important — to let such compromises deter me. I agree it is hypocritical, but once my work is done, I shall destroy the machines and do penance.
You genuinely mean it, don’t you? You really do loathe technology. The Catalyst must really get your back up!

For all the advantages it affords, it is like a sickness in the world. A disease of metal, smoke and oil encroaching over the land. The Catalyst is crudely, mindlessly attempting to accelerate the indigenous technology level. My work will not be done until every soul on this planet has turned away from the path of industrial progress.
So you made the machines go mad, and start creating monsters out of human flesh, just to scare everyone?
Yes. This is all a gruesome piece of grand guignol, to make people afraid of technology. Back to nature, indeed! Nature won’t protect them from you.
That is true, I’m afraid. And I need not protect you from them!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 137
F/X HUMANOIDS STEP ONTO THE GRASS.
Fresh! Flesh! Living! Flesh! [ETC]EVELYN:
Doctor? The creatures - they’re moving!
No — wait. Wait!
F/X CROWD STARTS BACKING AWAY.
Too late, Doctor. I had planned to use the people of this town as my disciples, to spread my gospel throughout the land. However, now that you have betrayed me, they are useless and
must be destroyed!
In which case — run, everyone! RUN!
F/X EVERYONE RUNS FOR IT.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 138
SCENE 81. INT. PUB
F/X CLANKING ALL AROUND.
That thing over there, is that the laser we’re looking for?
Yes, that’s it. I hope it comes ready charged, I doubt there’s anywhere round here where you can buy spare batteries.
Just got to squeeze past this one machine here. It’s going like the clappers!
Because it knows what’1l happen if we get hold of that laser. Pass me the glue gun.
Here, catch!
Right then. Here goes...
F/X BELFRAGE USES A GLUE GUN ON THE MACHINE, MACHINE IS
GUMMED UP BUT KEEPS FIGHTING THE GLUE.
Now, you make sure it doesn’t spring back into life while I’m underneath it.
Can you reach the laser?
I think so. Yes...
F/X BELFRAGE REACHES FOR LASER. CLUNK FROM MACHINE.
Boss, watch out. The machine’s not completely jammed.
Spray some more gunk into it then.
We’ve run out.
Come on, stupid thing, just one more inch —
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 139
F/X BELFRAGE STRETCHES A LITTLE FURTHER, GRABS THE LASER AND
FALLS BACK.
Got you!
F/X MACHINERY MOVES AGAIN, UNSTEADILY.
Look out, boss!
F/X SHUDDERING MACHINERY PILES INTO BELFRAGE.
HOWLS IN MORTAL AGONY
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 140
SCENE 82. INT. TRAIN STATION
F/X BLEEPING, WINKING TECHNOLOGY. DOOR BURSTS OPEN, DOCTOR,
EVELYN, CLARA AND STEPHEN RUN INSIDE.
If you’re planning on catching a train, Doctor, I think the ticket office is shut!
We’re not here to catch a train, we’re here to look for something. (SEARCHES) It must be here, it must be...
It might help if you told us what you were looking for?
The Catalyst made something that restored Stephen’s fingers. So there’s some sophisticated medical equipment here, and all we need is - ah-ha!
F/X DOCTOR TAPS AWAY AT A KEYPAD — BLEEPS IN TIME.
I find much of what the Doctor says utterly unfathomable.
Don’t worry, Miss Stretton — that’s partly because you’re from the nineteenth century and partly because the only person who
can understand what the Doctor is talking about is the Doctor.
One of those monster things is heading this way!
Good — that means it isn’t attacking anyone else.
They seem to be homing in on you...
F/X DISPENSER DISPENSES A SYRINGE — CLATTER INTO PAN. DOCTOR
KEEPS TAPPING AT KEYPAD.
Flattering, isn’t it? They must have decided I’m the bigger threat.
He wanted me to take your coat.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 14]
He what?
Father wanted me to take your coat. I never got the chance to ask why.
Doctor, maybe it’s something to [do with —]
Move away from the window, Miss Stretton!
F/X HUMANOID’S ARM SMASHES THROUGH WINDOW.
GROWLS
Its arm’s got caught on the glass.
F/X ANOTHER SYRINGE CLATTERS INTO PAN.
The perfect scenario to test my theory. Stephen, take one of these.
What’s this — more of your syringes?
Freshly dispensed. When I say ‘Now’, we both lunge forward, stab our syringes into its arm and push down on the plunger. Got it?
I think so.
Then — three, two, one - now!
F/X THEY LUNGE AND STAB THE HUMANOID.
SCREECH
Good — now get back, get back!
What was in those syringes, Doctor?
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 142
Anaesthetic.
F/X HUMANOID OUTSIDE MAKES WOOZY NOISES.
Ah yes! Human flesh...
Equals human nervous systems. Exactly.
F/X HUMANOID FALLS TO THE GROUND.
Sweet dreams!
Well done. Now, Doctor, about [your —]
Just a moment, Evelyn. Clara?
Yes?

We’1ll need many more of those. The code will be in the keypad’s last-number memory, so all you have to do is press this and then this, wait for the syringe to drop out of the bottom, and repeat as necessary. Understand?
Not remotely.
Good, that’s the spirit!
Doctor, I —
Stephen, find as many men as you can, arm them with syringes, and don’t stop until all the monsters are incapacitated!
They won’t all be as easy.
No, I know and I’m sorry, but it’s the best I can do. There’s a chance those creatures may be sentient, and if that’s the case then I have to try to free them.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 143
How?

There’s a controlling intelligence at work here, the ‘egg’ that was using your father as a puppet. I’ve seen similar devices used before — they’re called Inhibitors. Somebody has seen the rate at which Earth’s technology level is developing and decided they don’t approve.
Who?

No idea. If I can get my hands on the Inhibitor, maybe I can find out. Lots of races use them, it’s a disgrace, and against intergalactic law. They work in various ways, creating malfunctions, losing vital research, or just by making people scared of technology. That must be why it targeted Ackleton - it homed in on the most advanced technology it could find.
Mr Belfrage’s Catalyst.
Exactly!
Doctor, are you speaking of people from other worlds?
Yes, I am. I advise you to nod quietly and accept it. But what I need to find is —
A tool to reprogram the Inhibitor and stop all this?
Yes.
I think it’s in your coat pocket.
What? (BEAT) The device I found in Belfrage’s office!
F/X SMALL HI-TECH TOOL NOISE AS DOCTOR TAKES OUT DEVICE.
The Catalyst knew it was under threat. So what did it do? It tried to deliver the solution to Belfrage!
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 144
It seems the Catalyst is slightly brighter than Belfrage. Which to be fair, isn’t particularly difficult.
Which is why Stretton wanted your coat, because he could sense it was in your pocket.
Of course! Come on — we’1ll make our way into the factory through the cellars.
F/X THEY HEAD OFF.
Good luck!
(OFF) You too!
I’m still not sure I understand what they are doing.
You’re not the only one.
Regardless, we have work to do. Now, the sequence is
Significant...
F/X CLARA PRESSES KEYPAD BUTTONS. FADE.
INDUSTRIAL EVOLUTION by Eddie Robson (004) Page 145
SCENE 83. INT. PUB
Mr Belfrage? Boss? Are you-?
(TRAPPED BENEATH MACHINERY, MORTALLY WOUNDED) Not so good, Brewster. I can’t seem to feel my legs.
Yeah, there’s all this stuff piled up on top of them. Don’t panic, I’ve got a plan. Have you still got that laser?
Er, yes —
Right. (EFFORT) (FX: MACHINERY CREAKS) I’1ll see if I can’t take the weight. — You, you see if you can’t cut through whatever’s holding your legs — (BEAT) Come on, boss, get on with it!
It’s no good, Brewster. Really. No good.
(F/X: MACHINERY CREAKS AS BREWSTER LETS GO GENTLY.) Right. I’1ll go and see if I can’t find something to prop this lot up with, then I’ll see if I can’t get beneath there myself.
No. No. Reach in here and see if you can’t take the laser, and the control... control whatchermakallit...
(REACHING) Whatever you say —
Hurry it up, eh? I don’t have a very high... pain threshold.
Yeah, gottem. Right, I’1l just be two ticks — (BREAKS OFF) Hang about — purple. My hands are all covered in... purple...
It’s blood, Brewster. Now, please, find the Doctor. He’1ll know what... what to — (FADES AWAY, PRESUMED DEAD)
Boss? (BEAT) Mr Belfrage? (PAUSE) Oh, you daft old — [idiot].
